markdownRemark.html:
Describing a SARIMA Model

  • A SARIMA model is an ARIMA model that accounts for seasonality
  • Here, seasonality just refers to a repeating pattern within a year (i.e. can't be a two-year pattern)

  • A SARIMA model is defined as the following:

    ARIMA(p,d,q)(P,D,Q)mARIMA(p,d,q)(P,D,Q)mARIMA(p,d,q)(P,D,Q)m
    • Where ppp refers to the order of the autoregressive portion of the ARIMA model
    • Where ddd refers to the order of the integrated portion of the ARIMA model (i.e. how many times we take a difference to get our model to be stationary)
    • Where qqq refers to the order of the moving average portion of the ARIMA model
    • Where mmm refers to the seasonal factor (i.e. the number of distinct periods within a year that make up a single seasonal pattern that is repeated over time)
    • Where PPP refers to the order of the autoregressive portion of the ARIMA model, with an additional seasonal component
    • Where DDD refers to the order of the integrated porition of the ARIMA model, with an additional seasonal component
    • Where QQQ refers to the order of the order of the moving average porition of the ARIMA model, with an additional seasonal component
  • A SARIMA model can also be written as an ARIMA model:
ARIMA(p,d,q)1(P,D,Q)mARIMA(p,d,q)_{1}(P,D,Q)mARIMA(p,d,q)1​(P,D,Q)m
  • This is because we're technically backshifting parameters p,d,p, d,p,d, and qqq by 111 (i.e. st+1−sts_{t+1} - s_{t}st+1​−st​)

Example of SARIMA Model

  • Let's say we define the following SARIMA model:
ARIMA(1,0,0)(0,1,1)4ARIMA(1,0,0)(0,1,1)_{4}ARIMA(1,0,0)(0,1,1)4​

  • The ppp parameter with a value equal to 111 can be translated to the following:

    (1−ϕ1B1)yt(1-\phi_{1}B^{1})y_{t}(1−ϕ1​B1)yt​
    • Where B1ytB^{1}y_{t}B1yt​ is our lag operator representing yt−1y_{t-1}yt−1​
    • Where ϕ1\phi_{1}ϕ1​ is the slope of our variable yt−1y_{t-1}yt−1​
    • Therefore, (1−ϕ1B1)yt(1-\phi_{1}B^{1})y_{t}(1−ϕ1​B1)yt​ is just shorthand for yt−ϕ1yt−1y_{t}-\phi_{1}y_{t-1}yt​−ϕ1​yt−1​

  • The DDD parameter with a value equal to 111 can be translated to the following:

    (1−B4)yt(1-B^{4})y_{t}(1−B4)yt​
    • Where B4ytB^{4}y_{t}B4yt​ is our lag operator representing yt−4y_{t-4}yt−4​
    • Therefore, (1−B4)yt(1-B^{4})y_{t}(1−B4)yt​ is just shorthand for z=yt−yt−4z = y_{t}-y_{t-4}z=yt​−yt−4​

  • The QQQ parameter with a value equal to 111 can be translated to the following:

    (1+θ1B4)ϵt(1+\theta_{1}B^{4})\epsilon_{t}(1+θ1​B4)ϵt​

    • Where B4ϵtB^{4}\epsilon_{t}B4ϵt​ is our lag operator representing ϵt−4\epsilon_{t-4}ϵt−4​

      • Where ϵt−4\epsilon_{t-4}ϵt−4​ is the error of the fourth previous predicted value and what we observed
      • Where θ1\theta_{1}θ1​ represents the percentage of the error ϵt−4\epsilon_{t-4}ϵt−4​ we should include in our model
      • Therefore, (1−θ1B4)ϵt(1-\theta_{1}B^{4})\epsilon_{t}(1−θ1​B4)ϵt​ is just shorthand for ϵt+θ1ϵt−4\epsilon_{t}+\theta_{1}\epsilon_{t-4}ϵt​+θ1​ϵt−4​
  • We can continue to simplify our SARIMA model to the following formulas:
(1−ϕ1B1)(1−B4)yt=(1+θ1B4)ϵt(1-\phi_{1}B^{1})(1-B^{4})y_{t} = (1+\theta_{1}B^{4})\epsilon_{t}(1−ϕ1​B1)(1−B4)yt​=(1+θ1​B4)ϵt​ (1−ϕ1B1−B4+ϕ1B5)yt=ϵt+θ1ϵt−4(1-\phi_{1}B^{1}-B^{4}+\phi_{1}B^{5})y_{t} = \epsilon_{t}+\theta_{1}\epsilon_{t-4}(1−ϕ1​B1−B4+ϕ1​B5)yt​=ϵt​+θ1​ϵt−4​ yt−ϕ1yt−1−yt−4+ϕ1yt−5=ϵt+θ1ϵt−4y_{t} - \phi_{1}y_{t-1} - y_{t-4} + \phi_{1}y_{t-5} = \epsilon_{t} + \theta_{1}\epsilon_{t-4}yt​−ϕ1​yt−1​−yt−4​+ϕ1​yt−5​=ϵt​+θ1​ϵt−4​ yt−yt−4=ϕ1yt−1−ϕ1yt−5+θ1ϵt−4+ϵty_{t} - y_{t-4} = \phi_{1}y_{t-1} - \phi_{1}y_{t-5} + \theta_{1}\epsilon_{t-4} + \epsilon_{t}yt​−yt−4​=ϕ1​yt−1​−ϕ1​yt−5​+θ1​ϵt−4​+ϵt​ zt=ϕ1zt−1+θ1ϵt−4+ϵtz_{t} = \phi_{1}z_{t-1} + \theta_{1}\epsilon_{t-4} + \epsilon_{t}zt​=ϕ1​zt−1​+θ1​ϵt−4​+ϵt​
  • Since z=yt−yt−4z = y_{t}-y_{t-4}z=yt​−yt−4​ is based on parameter DDD
  • Now, we've transformed our ARIMA model to account for seasonality by taking differences yt−yt−4y_{t} - y_{t-4}yt​−yt−4​, which will lead to a more stationary model
